The electronic ground state is \(1s\;(n=1,\ell =0)\).  
Because \(\ell =0\),

\[
{\bf J}= {\bf L}+{\bf S}= {\bf S},\qquad 
J=\tfrac12 .
\]

The nucleus (the proton) carries spin  

\[
{\bf I},\qquad I=\tfrac12 .
\]

Hence the only possible values of the total angular momentum  

\[
{\bf F}= {\bf I}+{\bf J}
\]

are  

\[
F=0\quad (\text{singlet})\qquad\hbox{and}\qquad F=1\quad (\text{triplet}),
\]
with degeneracies \(2F+1\).

### Contact‐interaction Hamiltonian  

In the non‑relativistic limit the dominant contribution comes from the
magnetic‑dipole contact term (Fermi contact interaction)

\[
\boxed{\,H_{\rm hf}=A\,{\bf I}\!\cdot\!{\bf J}\,},
\tag{1}
\]

where  

\[
A=
\frac{2}{3}\mu _0\,g_e\mu _B\,g_p\mu _N |\psi_{1s}(0)|^{2},
\qquad   
|\psi_{1s}(0)|^{2}= \frac{1}{\pi a_0^{3}} ,
\tag{2}
\]

\(g_e\simeq -2.002319\) (electron gyromagnetic ratio),
\(g_p\simeq 5.585694\) (proton gyromagnetic ratio).
Since \(g_e<0\) while \(g_p>0\), the product \(g_e g_p\) is **negative**, therefore  

\[
A<0 .
\]

(It is customary to keep the explicit sign rather than redefining
\(A\to |A|\).)

Using  

\[
{\bf I}\!\cdot\!{\bf J}= \frac12\bigl[F(F+1)-I(I+1)-J(J+1)\bigr],
\tag{3}
\]

the eigenenergies become  

\[
E_F = \frac{A}{2}\Bigl[F(F+1)-\underbrace{I(I+1)}_{3/4}-\underbrace{J(J+1)}_{3/4}\Bigr].
\tag{4}
\]

Insert the two admissible values of \(F\):

* **Triplet   \(F=1\):**
  \[
  E_{F=1}= \frac{A}{2}\left[2-\frac34-\frac34\right]
          =\frac{A}{4}.
  \]

* **Singlet    \(F=0\):**
  \[
  E_{F=0}= \frac{A}{2}\left[0-\frac34-\frac34\right]
          =-\frac{3A}{4}.
  \]

With \(A<0\) we obtain  

\[
E_{F=1}=+\frac{|A|}{4}\;\;>\;\;
E_{F=0}= -\frac{3|A|}{4}.
\]

Consequently the **aligned‑spin (triplet) level \(F=1\)** lies **above**
the antiparallel‑spin (singlet) level \(F=0\).

corresponding to the transition \(F=1\rightarrow F=0\)
at \(\nu = 1.42040575177\times10^{9}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\).

**(b) Rotational‑nuclear‑spin splitting of the H₂ molecule**

Two identical nuclei (protons) each carry spin \(i=½\).  
Their combined nuclear‑spin states are

\[
\begin{array}{ccl}
\displaystyle I_{\rm tot}=0 &:& \text{singlet }(|\uparrow\downarrow\rangle-
|\downarrow\uparrow\rangle)/\sqrt2\quad\text{(antisymmetric)},\\[4pt]
\displaystyle I_{\rm tot}=1 &:& \text{triplet }
\begin{cases}
|\uparrow\uparrow\rangle,\\
(|\uparrow\downarrow\rangle+
 |\downarrow\uparrow\rangle)/\sqrt2,\\
|\downarrow\downarrow\rangle
\end{cases}
\quad\text{(symmetric)} .
\end{array}
\]

The full molecular wavefunction may be written (Born–Oppenheimer approximation)

\[
\Psi({\bf r}_e,{\bf R};\sigma_i)=
\Phi_{\rm el}({\bf r}_e;R)\;
\chi_{\rm vib}(R)\;
Y_{JM_J}(\hat R)\;
\Xi_{I M_I}^{\,(p)},
\tag{5}
\]

where  

* \(\Phi_{\rm el}\) – electronic ground state \(^1\Sigma_g^{+}\) (spatially symmetric);
* \(\chi_{\rm vib}\) – vibrational ground state (also symmetric);
* \(Y_{JM_J}\) – spherical harmonic describing the **rotational** motion;
* \(\Xi_{IM_I}^{\,(p)}\) – nuclear‑spin function, superscript \(p=s,t\) indicating
symmetrisation.

Protons are **fermions**; interchange of the two nuclei must give an **overall
antisymmetric** wavefunction:

\[
P_{12}\,\Psi = -\Psi .
\tag{6}
\]

Under particle exchange,

* the electronic × vibrational factors stay unchanged (they are symmetric);
* the rotational function acquires a factor \((-1)^J\):
  \(
  P_{12} Y_{JM_J}= (-1)^J Y_{JM_J};
  \)
* the nuclear‑spin function changes according to its symmetry:
  \(
  P_{12}\,\Xi^{\,(s)} = -\Xi^{\,(s)}
  \) (antisymmetric singlet) and
  \(
  P_{12}\,\Xi^{\,(t)} = +\Xi^{\,(t)}
  \) (symmetric triplet).

Therefore condition (6) forces

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Singlet nuclear spin }(I_{\rm tot}=0)&\Longleftrightarrow &
\;J\;\text{even (including }J=0\text{)} ,\\[2mm]
&\text{Triplet nuclear spin }(I_{\rm tot}=1)&\Longleftrightarrow&
\;J\;\text{odd (minimum }J=1\text{)} .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{7}
\]

The rotational energy (rigid rotor) is  

\[
E_{\rm rot}(J)=B\,J(J+1),\qquad 
B = \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2I_{\rm mol}},
\tag{8}
\]

for H₂ \(B/k_{\rm B}\approx 85.4\;{\rm K}\) (or \(B/h\approx 59.3\;{\rm GHz}\)).
Consequences:

* **Para‑hydrogen** (singlet, \(I_{\rm tot}=0\)): the lowest permissible
rotation is \(J=0\Rightarrow E_{\rm rot}=0\). This is the absolute ground
state of the molecule.

* **Ortho‑hydrogen** (triplet, \(I_{\rm tot}=1\)): the smallest allowed
rotational quantum number is \(J=1\), giving  

\[
E_{\rm rot}(J=1)=B\;1\!\times\!2 = 2B\; (>0).
\]

Thus the triplet nuclear‑spin configuration necessarily possesses additional
rotational kinetic energy and sits **higher** in energy than the singlet.

```
Energy ↑
│                ┌─────┐   (I_tot = 1, J = 1,2,… )  ← ortho‑H₂
│                │     │
│                │  •  │   (first excited rotational level)
│                └─────┘
│
│   ────────────────────────────   (I_tot = 0, J = 0 )
│        ↓   para‑H₂ (ground state)
│
```

### Final statements

* **Atomic case:** the hyperfine level with total angular momentum
\(F=1\) (parallel electron–proton spins) lies **higher** than the
\(F=0\) level.

* **Molecular case:** the nuclear‑spin **triplet** state (ortho‑H₂) is forced
to rotate with \(J\ge 1\) and consequently resides **higher** in energy than
the nuclear‑spin **singlet** state (para‑H₂), whose lowest rotational
level is \(J=0\).

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&(a)\qquad E_{F=1}>E_{F=0}, \\[2mm]
&(b)\qquad \text{Triplet (ortho‑H}_{2})\;>\;\text{Singlet (para‑H}_{2}) .
\end{aligned}}
\]

assistantfinal**(a) Why heavy nuclei α‑decay but do **not** emit a free neutron**

For any decay mode the released \(Q\)–value must be positive  

\[
Q=X_{\text {initial}}-\sum_i X_{\,{\rm products}}>0 .
\]

Using the semi‑empirical (Bethe–Weizsäcker) mass formula   

\[
B(Z,N)=a_VA-a_SA^{2/3}-a_C\frac{Z(Z-1)}{A^{1/3}}
      -a_A\frac{(N-Z)^2}{A}\pm\Delta ,
\qquad   A=N+Z,
\]
the two relevant \(Q\)’s read  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
Q_\alpha &= B(Z-2,N-2)+B(\alpha)-B(Z,N)\;,\\[2mm]
Q_n     &= B(Z,N-1)-B(Z,N)
          =-S_n\;( {\rm neutron\;separation}) .
\end{aligned}}
\]

---

*Alpha decay*

Insert the mass formula and keep only the dominant terms (\(A\gg 1\)).  
With \(B(\alpha)=28.30\;\mathrm{MeV}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
Q_\alpha &\approx 
    4a_V-4a_SA^{-1/3}+a_CA^{-1/3}(2Z-2)(2Z-3) \\[-1mm]
&\quad -4a_A\frac{(N-Z)^2}{A}
           +\hbox{pairing corrections}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The first three contributions scale approximately as  

\[
Q_\alpha\simeq 4a_V-
            \underbrace{4a_S}_{\propto A^{2/3}}\!A^{-1/3}
            +\underbrace{a_C}_{\propto Z^2/A^{1/3}},
\]

so that for growing proton number the repulsive Coulomb term
\(a_C Z^2/A^{1/3}\) overtakes the loss of surface energy.
Numerically one finds  

\[
Q_\alpha>0\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad Z\gtrsim 84,\;
A\gtrsim 210 .
\]

Thus very heavy nuclides possess a **positive** \(Q_\alpha\) and can
spontaneously tunnel through the Coulomb barrier (“α‑radioactivity”).

---

*Neutron emission*

For neutron emission the \(Q\)–value equals minus the neutron‑separation
energy,

\[
Q_n=-S_n ,\qquad   
S_n=B(Z,N)-B(Z,N-1).
\]

From the mass formula  

\[
S_n\simeq a_V-a_SA^{-1/3}
        -a_A\frac{4(N-Z)+1}{A}
        \pm\Delta .
\]

All coefficients except the asymmetry term are **positive**, therefore
\(S_n\) stays **large and positive** well beyond the valley of stability.
Only when the excess of neutrons reaches the “neutron drip line’’ does
\(S_n\rightarrow 0\) and \(Q_n\) become able to turn positive.  
Consequently ordinary heavy nuclei are **stable against single‑neutron
emission**; they would have to climb an energetic hill before losing a
free neutron.

Hence heavy systems satisfy  

\[
Q_\alpha>0\,,\qquad Q_n<0,
\]

explaining why they α‑decay yet remain bound with respect to neutron
evaporation.

#### 2. Sequential Stern–Gerlach devices (quantum‐state tomography)

ensembles, aligning the field gradients successively along the three
orthogonal directions \(z,x,y\):

beam ──► SG(z) ► count_up(z), count_down(z)
          │
          ▼

               SG(x) ……
               SG(y) ……

\[
\langle S_z\rangle =\frac{\hbar}{2}\,(f_z^{(u)}-f_z^{(d)}),

\langle S_x\rangle =\frac{\hbar}{2}\,(f_x^{(u)}-f_x^{(d)}),

\]

  \((0,+\hbar/2,0).\)

#### 3. Interferometric reconnection of the split paths  

Leave the two branches emerging from the first SG‑\(z\) untouched,
let them travel parallel, and finally bring them together with a
magnetic “recombiner’’ that erases their path information (an analogue of

## Summary

  * Alternatively, perform Stern–Gerlach measurements along several
    mutually perpendicular axes (full state tomography) or employ a
    spin‑interferometer that restores coherence between the split paths.

\(S_x\) eigenstate, a definite \(S_y\) eigenstate, or an incoherent
mixture (unpolarised).  

\[
\boxed{

\text{(i) one spot;}\\[2pt]
\text{(ii)--(iv) two equal spots, distinguished only by a preceding}\\
\text{rotation or by complementary SG measurements.}
\end{array}}
\]

Let's craft answer.assistantfinal**Explanation**

Even if the strong‑force part of the nucleon–nucleon interaction were completely charge independent – i.e. the “specific” nuclear force has the same strength for every \(nn,\;pp\) and \(np\) pair – the **total** binding energy of a nucleus contains two other contributions  

* the long‑range **Coulomb repulsion** acting only between protons,
* the kinetic‐energy contribution coming from the Pauli exclusion principle (the “symmetry’’ term).

These two effects make the energetically most favourable configuration change with the size of the nucleus.  
The simplest quantitative description is provided by the semi‑empirical (liquid‑drop) mass formula

\[
B(N,Z)=a_{v}\!A-a_{s}\!A^{2/3}
      -a_{c}\frac{Z(Z-1)}{A^{1/3}}
      -a_{a}\frac{(N-Z)^{2}}{A}+{\rm pairing},
\qquad   A=N+Z .
\tag{1}
\]

All coefficients (\(a_{v},a_{s},a_{c},a_{a}>0\)) are constants determined empirically;
\(a_{c}=0.71\,\text{MeV}\) measures the Coulomb repulsion, whereas 
\(a_{a}=23.2\,\text{MeV}\) quantifies how much energy is lost when the numbers of neutrons and protons become unequal (Pauli‑principle effect).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1. Why do heavy stable nuclei contain many more neutrons?

For a fixed mass number \(A\) the most tightly bound isotope is obtained by maximising \(B\), i.e. by setting  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial B}{\partial Z}\right) _{A}=0 .
\]

From Eq.(1),

\[
-\;a_{c}\,\frac{2Z-1}{A^{1/3}}
    +a_{a}\,\frac{4(N-Z)}{A}=0 ,
\]

which after neglecting the small ‘‑1’ term gives the familiar result

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle \frac{N-Z}{A}\;\approx\;
\frac{a_{c}}{2a_{a}}\;A^{2/3}
}
\tag{2}
\]

or equivalently   

\[
N\simeq Z+\frac{a_{c}}{2a_{a}}\,A^{2/3}.
\]

Because the factor \(A^{2/3}\) grows rapidly with the size of the nucleus, the right‑hand side becomes appreciable already for moderate masses:
for \(A\sim 50\) the correction is \(\sim0.05A\) (about three extra neutrons);
for \(A\sim200\) it reaches \(\sim0.12A\) (roughly twenty‑four extra neutrons).
Hence **light nuclei can stay close to \(N=Z\)**, whereas **heavy stable nuclei must possess a substantial neutron excess** in order to compensate the growing Coulomb repulsion among their many protons.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Separation energies: why does it take more energy to knock out a proton than a neutron from a heavy stable nucleus?

Define the single‑particle separation (removal) energies

\[
S_{n}(N,Z)=B(N,Z)-B(N-1,Z),
\qquad   
S_{p}(N,Z)=B(N,Z)-B(N,Z-1).
\]

In the liquid‑drop picture the dominant parts of these quantities are just the negative of the corresponding chemical potentials,

\[
\mu_{n}= -\Bigl(\frac{\partial M}{\partial N}\Bigr)_{Z},
\qquad    
\mu_{p}= -\Bigl(\frac{\partial M}{\partial Z}\Bigr)_{N},
\]
with \(M=A m_{\!u}-B/c^{2}\).

Taking the derivative of Eq.(1) with respect to \(N\) and \(Z\) separately (and again discarding the tiny surface‑pairing corrections) yields

\[
\begin{aligned}
S_{n}&\simeq a_{v}-a_{s}A^{-1/3}
        -a_{a}\frac{4(N-Z)+2}{A},\\[2mm]
S_{p}&\simeq a_{v}-a_{s}A^{-1/3}
        -a_{c}\frac{2Z-1}{A^{1/3}}
        -a_{a}\frac{-4(N-Z)+2}{A}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{3}
\]

On the valley of β‑stability the relationship (2) holds, i.e.  

\[
N-Z=\frac{a_{c}}{2a_{a}}A^{2/3}.
\]

Insert this into Eqs.(3):

\[
\begin{aligned}
S_{n}&\simeq a_{v}-a_{s}A^{-1/3}
          -2a_{c}A^{1/3}+O(A^{-1}), \\[2mm]
S_{p}&\simeq a_{v}-a_{s}A^{-1/3}
          +2a_{c}A^{1/3}+O(A^{-1}) .
\end{aligned}
\tag{4}
\]

The **Coulomb term appears with opposite sign**.  
For a heavy nucleus (\(A\gtrsim100\)), the magnitude of the last term,
\(2a_{c}A^{1/3}\), far exceeds the modest residual pieces proportional to
\(A^{-1/3}\). Consequently

\[
\boxed{S_{p}>S_{n}\quad\text{(stable heavy nuclei)}} .
\]

Physically this means:

*Removing a neutron* brings the system **closer** to the optimal \(N/Z\) dictated by Eq.(2); the reduction of the symmetry‑penalty partially compensates the loss of nuclear binding, so relatively little energy is needed.

*Removing a proton*, instead, **increases** the Coulomb stress (because there remain almost as many protons left behind) and simultaneously drives the nucleus away from its preferred \(N/Z\) value. Both effects raise the amount of energy that must be supplied—hence the larger proton separation energy.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Summary

* The equality of the underlying strong force makes the **volume** and **surface** components of the binding energy depend only on the total nucleon number \(A\).  
* The **Coulomb repulsion**, which scales like \(Z^{2}/A^{1/3}\), grows faster than the attractive strong component as the nucleus gets heavier. To offset this rising repulsive energy, nature favours configurations with **extra neutrons**, producing the empirical trend \(N>Z\) for heavy stable nuclides [Eq.(2)].
* On the valley of stability the competition between the Coulomb term and the symmetry term fixes a particular \(N/Z\) ratio. When a **neutron** is removed the symmetry term is reduced, partly cancelling the loss of binding, whereas removing a **proton** eliminates some Coulomb repulsion but also pushes the nucleus farther from the optimal \(N/Z\). The net result is a **larger proton separation energy** than neutron separation energy for heavy nuclei [Eqs.(3)–(4)].

Thus, even with perfectly charge‑independent nuclear forces, the presence of electric repulsion together with the Pauli‑exclusion driven symmetry energy explains both observations. 

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\frac{N-Z}{A}\;\approx\;\frac{a_{c}}{2a_{a}}\,A^{2/3},
\qquad 
S_{p}>S_{n}\ {\rm for\ stable\ heavy\ nuclei}
}
\]

In the Coulomb gauge the interaction Hamiltonian for one‑photon emission is

matrix element

\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\hbar c}{V\omega}}
\;\boldsymbol\epsilon_{\mathbf k\lambda}^{\,*}\!
\cdot\!\langle f|\mathbf r|i\rangle } .
\]

\langle 1s|\mathbf r|

\end{aligned}
\]

\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\hbar c}{V\omega}}\;

\cdot\!\langle 1s|\mathbf r|2p_{1/2}\rangle } .
\]

If the parity‑violating interaction were turned off (\(\varepsilon\to0\)),

\[

\Gamma_{E1}\propto\varepsilon^{2},\qquad
\Gamma_{E1}\xrightarrow[]{\varepsilon\to0}=0 }
\]

Deuteron/triton similarly.

Also mention clustering effect: α preformed due to strong four-nucleon correlation.

Let's craft answer.assistantfinal**Answer**

Heavy‑mass nuclei (\(Z\gtrsim 80\)) sit above the line of β –stability and therefore possess a surplus of electric charge.  
To reduce this charge they can emit a charged fragment.  

The competition between possible decay modes is governed mainly by   

*the amount of energy liberated* \(Q\)   (which determines whether the process is **allowed**)   
and   
*the height and width of the Coulomb barrier* that the emitted fragment has to tunnel through.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a) Energy release  

For any binary decay  

\[
Q=\bigl[M_{\text {parent}}-(M_{\text {daughter}}+M_{\text {cluster}})\bigr ]c^{2}.
\]

Because nuclear masses differ only by a few tens of MeV, the sign and magnitude of \(Q\) depend almost entirely on the **binding energy of the emitted cluster** relative to the same number of nucleons left behind in the daughter.

| Emitted cluster | Binding energy of the cluster (≈) | Typical \(Q\) for heavy parents |
|-----------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------------|
| \(\alpha\;( ^4{\rm He})\) | \(B_\alpha\simeq 28\,\mathrm{MeV}\) (very compact, doubly magic) | \(Q\approx 4\!-\!10\;\mathrm{MeV}>0\) |
| p                | none (single nucleon)            | \(Q=-S_{p}<0\) (separation energies 5–10 MeV) |
| d (=pn)          | \(B_{d}=2.2\;\mathrm{MeV}\)       | \(Q\lesssim 0\) (needs break of two NN pairs) |
| t (=pnn)         | \(B_{t}=8.5\;\mathrm{MeV}\)        | usually \(Q<0\) |
| symmetric fission (two fragments \(A\!\sim\!A/2\)) | sum of fragment bindings ≃ bulk binding ± surface & Coulomb terms | \(Q\sim 150\!-\!250\;\mathrm{MeV}\) (large) |

Only the α‑particle carries a **large intrinsic binding energy per nucleon** (∼7 MeV/nucleon) together with a closed‑shell structure \((N=Z=2)\). Removing a single proton, a deuteron or a triton does **not** give a net gain in binding; consequently most heavy nuclei have **negative or marginally positive \(Q\)** for these channels, rendering them strongly suppressed. Spontaneous fission does supply a huge \(Q\), but it competes against a vastly larger collective barrier (see below).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Coulomb barrier  

The electrostatic potential felt by a point‑like fragment of charge \(Z_c e\) leaving a daughter of charge \(Z_d e\) is approximated by  

\[
V_C(r)=\frac{Z_c Z_d e^{2}}{r},\qquad 
r\approx r_{0}\Bigl[(A_c)^{1/3}+(A_d)^{1/3}\Bigr],
\]
with \(r_{0}\simeq1.2\ {\rm fm}\).

Using a representative heavy parent (\(Z_P\!=\!92,\;A_P\!=\!238\))

| Cluster | \(Z_c\) | Approximate barrier height \(V_B\) |
|---------|--------|------------------------------------|
| \(\alpha\)      | 2 | \(V_B\approx \displaystyle\frac{2(Z_P-2)}{r}\simeq 35\!-\!40\ {\rm MeV}\) |
| proton           | 1 | \(V_B\approx \displaystyle\frac{1(Z_P-1)}{r}\simeq 18\!-\!22\ {\rm MeV}\) |
| deuteron (or triton) | 1 | essentially the same as a proton (radius a little larger ⇒ slightly lower) |
| fission fragment (e.g. \(Z\!\sim\!46\)) | ∼46 | \(V_B\approx \displaystyle\frac{46\times46}{r}\sim 180\!-\!210\ {\rm MeV}\) |

Although the **geometrical barrier for a lone proton is numerically lower**, the decisive quantity for quantum tunnelling is the exponential Gamow factor  

\[
P\propto\exp\!\left[-2\int_{r_i}^{r_o}
\sqrt{\frac{2m}{\hbar^{2}}\,[V_C(r)-E]}dr\right].
\]

Here \(E\equiv Q\) is the kinetic energy available after decay.  
For proton (or d,t) emission we typically have \(Q\le 0\Rightarrow E\approx0\); the integrand stays large throughout the classically forbidden region, giving astronomically tiny probabilities.  

In contrast, for α‑decay the **positive \(Q\) (few MeV)** lifts the particle partway under the barrier, reducing the exponent dramatically. Moreover, the **pre‑formation probability** of an α‑cluster inside a heavy nucleus is unusually high (because of the especially strong four‑nucleon correlation and the double‑magic nature of \(^4\)He). Consequently the overall decay constant  

\[
\lambda = P_{\text{form}}\,\nu\,P_{\text{penetration}}
\]

is orders of magnitude larger for α particles than for solitary nucleons.

Spontaneous fission enjoys a gigantic \(Q\) but faces a **much wider and taller collective barrier** (shape deformation, saddle-point energy ≳ 200 MeV). Only when the fissility parameter approaches unity (as in the heaviest trans‑actinides) does the fission rate become competitive with α‑decay; otherwise the α channel dominates.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## Summary  

* **Energy:** An α‑particle carries a large internal binding energy (≈ 28 MeV). Its emission yields a sizeable positive \(Q\) for virtually all heavy nuclei, whereas proton, deuteron or triton emission generally have zero or negative \(Q\) and are thus energetically forbidden or highly hindered.  

* **Barrier:** Although the Coulomb barrier for a single proton is modest, the absence of released kinetic energy makes the tunnelling probability negligible. The α‑particle benefits simultaneously from a moderately sized barrier (**\(30\!-\!40\) MeV**) and a non‑zero kinetic energy equal to the positive \(Q\), producing a realistic tunnelling probability. In addition, the α‑cluster’s pre‑formation probability is far greater than that of any other light cluster.  

Consequently, **α‑decay is overwhelmingly preferred** over direct proton/deuteron/triton emission and over spontaneous fission for the majority of the heaviest naturally occurring radionuclides. 

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Large }Q_{\alpha}\ (>0) \quad+\quad \text{moderate Coulomb barrier}\\
&\Longrightarrow\ \text{highest decay probability among light‐cluster modes.}
\end{aligned}}
\]

In the semiclassical picture each electron moves in the one‑particle Hamiltonian

At absolute zero all single‑particle levels up to the Fermi surface are filled.

\]

### (b)   Relation \(\rho(\mathbf r)-\phi(\mathbf r)\)

\[

2\int_{\lvert {\bf p}\rvert\le p_{F}}\!\!

      =\frac{p_{F}^{3}({\bf r})}{3\pi^{2}\,\hbar^{3}},
\]

\]

In contrast, an unpolarised beam consists of many electrons each being either spin‑up or spin‑down with equal probability and without any fixed relative phase between them. This situation is correctly described only by a statistical mixture, using a density‐operator:

\[
\rho = \tfrac12\,|{\uparrow}_z\rangle\!\langle {\uparrow}_z|
      + \tfrac12\,|{\downarrow}_z\rangle\!\langle {\downarrow}_z|.
\]

Since a mixed state cannot be written as a single wavefunction, option (b) is the appropriate choice.

\[
\boxed{\text{(b) cannot be described by a wave function}}
\]

analysisWe need to interpret question: "Assume that there is an announcement of a fantastic process capable of putting the contents (i.e., text) of physics library on a very smooth postcard. Will it be readable with an electron microscope? Explain."

Interpretation: The idea is printing extremely small text onto a surface; can we read using EM? Need discuss resolution limits of electron microscopy vs physical size of letters, scattering etc.

Electron microscopes have high spatial resolution down to sub-nanometer (~0.1 nm). However reading requires contrast between ink/printing material and substrate. If it's just topography or composition differences detectable via SEM/TEM. Also practical issues: sample preparation, charging, damage from beam, depth-of-field, field of view limited. To read entire page you'd need scanning over huge area with nanometer steps - time-consuming but possible theoretically. Thus answer: In principle, electron microscope's resolution far exceeds needed for any realistic font size even if shrunk to few atoms across. So yes, one could image and decode given appropriate imaging mode (TEM/STEM), provided the pattern has enough mass/thickness difference and doesn't charge too much. Practical constraints: field of view, data volume, alignment, noise.

Let's craft explanation: compute minimal feature size required for legibility: human eye ~100 µm per letter; scaling factor maybe 10^6 reduction yields 0.1 µm = 100nm still above EM limit. Even extreme shrink to single atom width unrealistic due to quantum mechanical spread; but EM resolves <0.2 Å.

Therefore answer: Yes, electron microscope can see such tiny writing, assuming proper contrast and no destruction. Provide reasoning about resolution, diffraction limit, de Broglie wavelength λ= h/p; electrons accelerated to 200 keV have λ≈2.5 pm giving theoretical resolution ~0.05 nm after aberrations correction. Real instruments achieve ~50pm.

Also mention limitations: scanning speed, data processing, radiation damage, requirement of conductive coating.

assistantfinalThe short answer is **yes – in principle an electron‑microscope can resolve and therefore “read’’ lettering that has been reduced to the dimensions of a postage‑stamp**, provided the printed marks give a measurable contrast to the underlying card.  

Below is a step–by–step justification.

---

### 1.   Spatial resolution of modern electron microscopes  

* For a TEM operated at \(E\!=\!200~{\rm keV}\)

\[
\lambda_{\text{e}}=\frac{h}{p}=2.5\times10^{-12}\ {\rm m}
\]

so the diffraction‐limited spot size can be well below \(0.1\,\mathrm{nm}\).

* State‑of‑the‑art spherical‑aberration corrected STEMs routinely reach  
\(r\simeq 0.04{-}0.07\;\text{nm}\) (40–70 pm) lateral resolution.

Hence any structure larger than a few tenths of a nanometre can be imaged directly.

---

### 2.   How small does the “postcard” text have to be?

Even if the whole content of a several‑kilobyte physics book were compressed into a square centimetre, each character would occupy roughly

\[
A_{\text{char}}\sim\frac{(1\;\text{cm})^{2}}{N_{\text{chars}}}
          \approx\frac{10^{-4}\,\text{m}^{2}}{10^{7}}
          \approx 10^{-11}\,\text{m}^{2},
\]
corresponding to linear dimensions of order  

\[
d\sim\sqrt{A_{\text{char}}}\approx3\times10^{-6}\,\text{m}=3\;\mu\text{m}.
\]

That is already three orders of magnitude *larger* than the ∼0.1 nm resolution of an EM.  
If one tried to push the compression further—say to a true “atomic‑scale” glyph only a few atoms wide—the dimension would become ≲1 nm, which is still comfortably within the capability of current TEM/STEM instrumentation.

So **any conceivable printable font that fits on a smooth postcard will be many times bigger than the smallest resolvable feature** of an electron microscope.

---

### 3.   Contrast requirements  

An EM does not detect “ink colour”; it detects variations in:

| Property | Typical source of contrast |
|----------|----------------------------|
| Mass / thickness | Heavy‑metal particles, carbon deposits |
| Atomic number (Z‑contrast) | High‑Z elements appear brighter in HAADF-STEM |
| Crystallinity / phase | Diffraction contrast in TEM |

Consequently the written marks must differ chemically or structurally from the surrounding paper/substrate. This can be achieved in practice by:

* depositing a thin metallic line (as done in e‑beam lithography),
* using a polymer resist that cross‑links under exposure,
* applying a conductive sputtered coat (Au/Pt) over the whole card so that the exposed regions retain different thicknesses.

Without such contrast the electron beam would simply wash out the signal (especially in a non‑conductive cardboard that charges badly).

---

### 4.   Practical considerations  

| Issue | Effect & Mitigation |
|-------|---------------------|
| **Vacuum compatibility** | Many organic inks out‑gas; replace with inorganic pigments or metal films. |
| **Radiation damage** | A low dose scan suffices because the goal is structural—not spectroscopic—imaging. |
| **Field of view** | Modern scanners can stitch together thousands of frames; reading a full page would take minutes‑to‑hours, but is technically doable. |
| **Sample preparation** | Thin (<100 nm) sections improve transmission TEM; otherwise a surface‑scanning SEM with backscatter detection works fine. |

These points make the experiment cumbersome, yet none constitute a fundamental barrier.

---

### 5.   Verdict  

Because the ultimate resolving power of an electron microscope (\(\lesssim 0.05\;\text{nm}\)) vastly exceeds the minimum size of any realistically printable character on a postcard, **the text would indeed be observable and decipherable**—provided the markings generate adequate electron‑optical contrast and the specimen survives the necessary vacuum and irradiation conditions.

In other words, the limitation is not the microscope’s optics but rather the chemistry/materials used to encode the information.

---  

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle 
\text{Yes. An electron microscope can resolve and thus read ultra‑small lettering on a smooth postcard, }
\\
\text{assuming the printed marks create sufficient contrast and withstand the EM environment.}
}
\]

1. $p + p \rightarrow p + (p + n\pi)$,
2. $p + p \rightarrow (p + n\pi) + (p + m\pi)$,

### 1️⃣ Projectile on a stationary target  

Take the laboratory frame where the target proton is at rest:
\(p_2^\mu =(m,\mathbf 0)\).
Let the incident proton have total energy \(E\) (\(=K+m\)), momentum \(\mathbf p\).

Then  

\[
s = (p_1+p_2)^2 
    = m^2+m^2+2mE
    = 2m^2+2mE .
\tag{2}
\]

Equating (2) to the threshold value (1),

\[
2m^2+2mE = (2m+M)^2 .
\]

Solving for the incident **total** energy,

\[
E = m+\underbrace{2M+\frac{M^{2}}{2m}}_{\displaystyle K_{\min }} .
\]

Hence the **minimum kinetic energy** that the moving proton must possess is  

\[
\boxed{K_{\min}=2M+\dfrac{M^{2}}{2m}}\quad .
\]

(The factor \(m\) cancels out of the algebraic manipulation.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2️⃣ Two protons approaching each other with equal speed  

Now let the two protons have equal speeds \(|v|\) in opposite directions.
Their individual Lorentz factors are identical: \(\gamma = 1/\sqrt{1-v^{2}/c^{2}}\).

Because the spatial momenta cancel, the total four‑momentum in this “laboratory’’
frame is purely timelike:

\[
P^\mu = (E_{\rm tot},\mathbf 0),
\qquad  
E_{\rm tot}=2\gamma m .
\]

Consequently  

\[
s = P_\mu P^\mu = (2\gamma m)^2 = 4\gamma ^2 m^{2}.
\]

Threshold again requires \(\sqrt{s}=2m+M\):

\[
2\gamma m = 2m+M \Longrightarrow 
\gamma = 1+\frac{M}{2m}.
\]

The kinetic energy of **one** proton is therefore  

\[
K_{\;{\rm one}}
      = (\gamma-1)m = \frac{M}{2},
\]

and the **combined** kinetic energy of the pair is  

\[
\boxed{K_{\rm total}=M } .
\]

#### Summary  

*For a beam proton striking a stationary target:*  

\[
\boxed{K_{\min}=2M+\frac{M^{2}}{2m_p}} .
\]

*If the two protons collide head‑on with equal speeds:*  

\[
\boxed{K_{\rm per\;proton}= \tfrac12 M },\qquad   
\boxed{K_{\rm total}= M } .
\]

\[

p_\gamma ^2+(p_e^{(i)})^2+2p_\gamma\!\cdot\!p_e^{(i)} .

Because a photon is light‑like, \(p_\gamma ^2=0\); for a resting electron,

p_\gamma\!\cdot\!p_e^{(i)}
=\frac{\varepsilon}{c}(m_ec)=\frac{m_e\varepsilon}{c}.
\]

(p' _e)^2 = m_e^{2}c^{2}+2\,\frac{m_e\varepsilon}{c}
          = m_e^{2}c^{2}+2m_e\varepsilon .

\]

assistantfinal**1. Definition**

The **\(G\)-parity operator** is defined as  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
G \equiv C\,e^{ i\pi I_{2}}
      =C\,R_{y}(\pi ) }
\]

where  

* \(C\) – the ordinary charge‑conjugation operator,
* \(e^{ i\pi I_{2}}\;(= R_{y}(\pi ))\) – a rotation by \(180^\circ\) about the second axis in isospin space (\(I_{2}\)).

Acting on any member of an isovector multiplet this operation first turns the particle into its antiparticle (\(C\)), and then rotates the resulting state back into the original charge–state by a half‑turn in isospin space.  
Because pure charge‑conjugation is only defined for self‑conjugate (neutral) particles, \(G\) extends the concept of “charge‐conjugation” to whole isomultiplets such as the pion or rho families. It commutes with the strong Hamiltonian (to good approximation) and therefore provides a conserved quantum number for strong interactions, just as \(C\) does for neutral states.

---

### 2. Eigenvalue of \(G\)

For a state belonging to an isospin multiplet with total isospin \(I\),

\[
\boxed{ \; G = C\,(-1)^{I}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

because the rotation \(e^{i\pi I_{2}}\) produces a factor \((-1)^{I}\).

If the intrinsic charge‑conjugation eigenvalue of the neutral member of the multiplet is denoted by \(C_{\rm int}\),
then Eq.(1) becomes  

\[
G=C_{\rm int}\,(-1)^{I}.
\]

---

## 3. Pions

All three pions belong to an isotriplet \((I=1)\); the neutral pion has intrinsic charge‑conjugation  

\[
C(\pi ^0)=+1 .
\]

Hence, from (1),

\[
\boxed{G(\pi^{+,0,-})=(-1)^{1}\times(+1) = -1 } .
\]

Therefore **every single pion**, regardless of its electric charge, carries  

\[
G_\pi = -1 .
\]

### 3.1   A system of \(n\) pions  

Consider a multi‑pion state characterised by a total isospin \(I_{\! {\rm tot}}\) and a relative orbital angular momentum \(L\) (the latter comes from exchanging identical bosons). Using (1) for each pion and multiplying the factors one obtains

\[
G_{\;n\;\pi}=(-1)^{n}\,(-1)^{I_{\!\rm tot}}=
            (-1)^{\,n+I_{\!\rm tot}} ,
\qquad\text{or equivalently}\qquad   
G_{\;n\;\pi}=(-1)^{n}\,(-1)^{L},
\]

the last equality holding when the pions couple to a symmetric spatial wave function (so that \(I_{\!\rm tot}+L\) is even).  
In words :

* **Even number of pions:** \(G=+1\) if the total isospin (or the orbital part) is even, otherwise \(G=-1\).
* **Odd number of pions:** \(G=-1\) multiplied by the same isospin/orbital factor.

A frequently used compact form is  

\[
\boxed{ G(n\hbox{-}\pi)=(-1)^{\,n+I_{\!\rm tot}} } .
\]

---

## 4. \(G\)-parities of selected light mesons  

Below we apply Eq.(1).  Their quantum numbers are listed together with the intrinsic \(C\) value of their neutral component.

| Meson | Isospin \(I\) | Intrinsic \(C\) (for the neutral member) | \(G = C(-1)^{I}\) |
|-------|--------------|-------------------------------------------|-------------------|
| \(\boldsymbol{\rho}\,(J^{PC}=1^{--})\) | \(I=1\) | \(C(\rho^{0}) = -1\) | \(\displaystyle G_{\rho}=(-1)(-1)^{1}=+1\) |
| \(\boldsymbol{\omega}\,(J^{PC}=1^{--})\) | \(I=0\) | \(C(\omega)= -1\) | \(\displaystyle G_{\omega}=(-1)(-1)^{0}= -1\) |
| \(\boldsymbol{\phi}\,(J^{PC}=1^{--})\)    | \(I=0\) | \(C(\phi)= -1\) | \(\displaystyle G_{\phi}=(-1)(-1)^{0}= -1\) |
| \(\boldsymbol{\eta}\,(J^{PC}=0^{-+})\)   | \(I=0\) | \(C(\eta)= +1\) | \(\displaystyle G_{\eta}= (+1)(-1)^{0}= +1\) |

(The same pattern holds for the corresponding excited partners \(\rho',\;\omega',\;\phi'\) and for \(\eta'\).)

These \(G\)-parities correctly predict which strong decays are allowed:
* \(\rho\) (with \(G=+1\)) cannot decay strongly into an odd‑number of pions (which would carry \(G=-1\)).
* \(\omega,\phi\) (\(G=-1\)) readily decay into three pions (\(G=(-1)^{3}= -1\)).
* \(\eta\) (\(G=+1\)) cannot go directly to a single pion, consistent with observations.

---

\[

\begin{aligned}
& G(\pi^{\pm,0}) = -1,\\[2pt]
& G(n\hbox{-}\pi)=(-1)^{\,n+I_{\!\rm tot}}, \\[2pt]
& G_{\rho}=+1,\quad G_{\omega}=G_{\phi}=-1,\quad G_{\eta}=+1 .

### 1.  Two‑body elastic–collision equations

\[
m_\alpha v_i = -\,m_\alpha v' + MV ,
\qquad

\tag{1}
\]

(the target recoils forward).

\[
\frac12 m_\alpha v_i^{2}= \frac12 m_\alpha v'^{2}+ \frac12 M V^{2}.
\tag{2}
\]

Insert Eq.(1) into Eq.(2):

\[
v_i^{2}=v'^{2}+ \frac{m_\alpha}{M}\,(v_i+v')^{2}.
\]

Introduce the mass ratio  

\[
\mu\equiv\frac{m_\alpha}{M}= \frac{4}{16}= \frac14 .
\]

\[
v_i^{2}=v'^{2}+ \mu\bigl(v_i^{2}+2v_iv'+v'^{2}\bigr),
\]
which leads to the quadratic equation for the dimensionless quantity \(x=v'/v_i\),

\[
(1+\mu)x^{2}+2\mu x-(1-\mu)=0 .
\]

With \(\mu=1/4\),

\[
\frac54 x^{2}+ \frac12 x-\frac34 =0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
5x^{2}+2x-3=0,
\]

giving the physical root  

\[
x=\frac{-2+8}{10}=0.6 .

Thus  

\[

K_{\text{after}}=\tfrac12 m_\alpha v'^{2}=0.36\,K_{\text{before}} .

      =0.36-1 = -0.64 .
\]

### 1. What is *intrinsic* parity?

For a particle \(X\) we may ask whether a single‑particle state \(|\,{\bf p},s\rangle _X\) is an **eigenstate of the spatial–inversion operator**
\[
P:\;(t,\mathbf{x})\rightarrow(t,-\mathbf {x}),
\qquad 
P|\,\mathbf p , s\rangle_X=\eta_X |-\mathbf p , s\rangle_X ,
\]
with eigenvalue \(\eta_X\equiv {\rm parity}(X)=\pm 1\).
If such an eigenvalue exists, it is called the *intrinsic parity* of \(X\).

A necessary condition for \(\eta_X\) to be physically meaningful is:

> **The dynamics governing the creation, propagation and destruction of \(X\) must conserve parity.**  

Only then can experiments compare amplitudes related by space inversion and extract a unique sign.

---

### 2. Interactions and parity conservation

| Interaction   | Status of parity (\(P\)) |
|---------------|--------------------------|
| Strong        | Conserved                |
| Electromagnetic | Conserved               |
| Weak          | Maximally violated       |

Consequences:

* **Strong / EM processes:** If a particle appears *alone* (as an asymptotic state) in a reaction governed solely by these forces, the amplitude for the reaction and its mirror image differ only by the product of the intrinsic parities of the external particles. By measuring cross sections of suitably chosen reactions one can solve for those signs. This is exactly what has been done for hadrons such as the proton, neutron, pion, kaon, … .

* **Weak processes:** Since the underlying Hamiltonian itself changes sign under \(P\), there is **no symmetry relation** between a process and its mirrored counterpart. Hence the notion of assigning a unique eigenvalue \(\eta_X\) loses operational meaning—any value would be compatible with experiment because the theory already predicts different rates for left‑handed versus right‑handed configurations.

---

### 3. How the proton’s parity is determined

Consider a classic strong‐interaction reaction,
\[
\pi^- + p \;\longrightarrow\; n + \gamma .
\]
All four participants interact via the strong (and subsequently electromagnetic) force, both of which respect parity. Writing the matrix element schematically,

\[
\mathcal M \propto \eta_{\pi}\,\eta_{p}\,\eta_n\,\eta_\gamma \times f({\rm kinematics}),
\]

one measures the angular distribution of the emitted photon. Comparing this distribution with the prediction obtained after applying the parity operation yields the product \(\eta_p\eta_n\); together with independent information on the meson parity (\(\eta_\pi=-1\)), the **absolute sign of \(\eta_p\)** follows. Experiments consistently find

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \eta_{p}=+1 } .
\]

Because the proton also partakes in pure electromagnetic processes (elastic electron‑proton scattering, atomic spectroscopy, etc.), its parity remains a well‑defined quantum number.

### 4. Why the muon does **not** have a measurable intrinsic parity

The muon (\(\mu^\pm\)) is created and destroyed almost exclusively through the **weak charged current**, e.g.

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Production:}&\quad &\pi^+\to \mu^{+}+ \nu_\mu ,\\[2mm]
&\text{Decay:}&\quad &\mu^{-}\to e^{-}+ \bar\nu_e+\nu_\mu .
\end{aligned}
\]

## Determination of the quantum numbers of the \(\boldsymbol{\eta^{0}}\)

Below we use only experimentally established facts listed in (a)–(c).

### 1. Charge

In the dominant decay \(\eta\to 2\gamma\) there are no charged particles; the second most frequent decay \(\eta\to3\pi\) always produces a **net electric charge equal to zero** (either \(\pi^{+}\pi^{-}\pi^{0}\) or three neutral pions). Moreover, the production reaction (1) involves a negatively charged projectile and a positively charged target while the recoiling neutron is neutral; the missing‑mass object therefore cannot carry any net charge. Hence  

\[
Q(\eta^{0}) = 0 .
\]

### 2. Spin and Parity

* **Photon pair:** Two real photons couple to total angular momentum \(J=0\) or \(J=2\) when they emerge in relative orbital angular momentum \(L=0\) or \(L=2\). Experimentally the angular correlation between the two photons is completely isotropic, showing that only the **\(L=0\) configuration contributes**. Consequently the parent particle must have **total spin \(J=0\)**.

* **Parity:** Each photon has intrinsic parity \(-1\). With orbital angular momentum \(L=0\),

\[
P_{\gamma\gamma}= (-1)^{2}\times (-1)^{L}=+1 .
\]

Since the strong/electromagnetic interaction conserves parity, the parity of the mother equals that of the daughter system,

\[
P(\eta)=+1 .
\]

However, the conventional assignment for a pseudoscalar meson uses the definition \(P=(-1)^{L+1}\) for a quark–antiquark bound state; the extra minus sign comes from the internal fermionic structure. Combining the empirical result “the decay occurs with \(L=0\)” with the known transformation property of a quark–antiquark pair forces the **intrinsic parity of the \(\eta\) to be \(-1\)**. Thus  

\[
J^{P}(\eta)=0^{-},
\]
i.e. the \(\eta\) is a **pseudoscalar**.

* **C‑parity:** The two‑photon final state is symmetric under exchange; Bose statistics require the overall wave function to be symmetric, which for two identical vectors imposes **even charge conjugation**, \(C=+1\). Therefore  

\[
C(\eta)=+1 .
\]

Hence the complete set of discrete quantum numbers is  

\[
J^{PC}=0^{-+}.
\]

(The same conclusion follows from the three‑pion decay: three pseudoscalar pions in an \(L=0\) state have total \(J^{P}=0^{-}\) and, because the pions form an isoscalar combination, the resulting C‑parity is again \(+\!.\))

### 3. Isospin

Consider the isospin coupling in the production reaction (1). The initial state consists of a pion (\(I=1\)) and a proton (\(I=1/2\)). Their direct product decomposes as  

\[
1\otimes\frac12 = \frac32\oplus\frac12 .
\]

If the newly formed meson carried **isospin \(I=1\)** (an isotriplet like the pions), the final state \((\eta^{\pm},\eta^{0})+N\) would appear in **both** charge channels:

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\pi^{-}p\to\eta^{-}p &&\text{and}\\
&\pi^{-}p\to\eta^{0}n .
\end{aligned}
\]

Experimentally only the latter is observed, whereas searches for the former gave null results well below the level expected for an isovector meson. The simplest way to reconcile the data is to assign the meson **isospin singlet character**, \(I=0\). Then the isospin algebra reads  

\[
1\otimes\frac12 \xrightarrow[]{\;I_{\eta}=0\;} \frac12 ,
\]

so the only admissible final‑state is the neutron channel, exactly what is seen.

Consequently  

\[
I(\eta)=0,\qquad I_{3}(\eta)=0 .
\]

Because the electric charge obeys the Gell‑Mann–Nishijima relation  

\[
Q = I_{3} + \tfrac12(B+S),
\]

with baryon number \(B=0\) and strangeness \(S=0\) for a pure light‑quark meson, the vanishing values of \(I_{3}\) and \(B,S\) reproduce the already‑deduced neutrality.

All available experimental observations lead uniquely to the following quantum‑numbers assignment for the neutral \(\eta\)-meson:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{c}
\displaystyle J^{P}=0^{-},\\[4pt]
I=0,\quad I_{3}=0, \\[4pt]
Q=0,\\[4pt]
C=+1,\qquad m_{\eta}=548.8\ {\rm MeV}/c^{2}.
\end{array}}
\]

For a projectile proton of total energy \(E=T+m_{p}\) (\(T\) – its kinetic energy) and momentum \(\mathbf p\), while the target proton is at rest,

\[
P_{1}^{\mu}=(E,\mathbf p ),\qquad   
P_{2}^{\mu}=(m_{p},\mathbf 0).
\]

Hence  

\[
s =(P_{1}+P_{2})^{2}
    =m_{p}^{2}+m_{p}^{2}+2m_{p}E
    =2m_{p}^{2}+2m_{p}E .
\tag{1}
\]

---

Setting Eq.(1) equal to the squared threshold CM energy,

\[
2m_{p}^{2}+2m_{p}E_{\rm th}= (2m_{p}+m_{\pi })^{2}.
\]

Solving for the projectile’s total energy \(E_{\rm th}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
2m_{p}E_{\rm th}&=
(2m_{p}+m_{\pi })^{2}-2m_{p}^{2}\\
&=2m_{p}^{2}+4m_{p}m_{\pi }+m_{\pi }^{2},
\\[2mm]
E_{\rm th}&=m_{p}+2m_{\pi }+\frac{m_{\pi }^{2}}{2m_{p}} .
\end{aligned}
\]

The required **kinetic** energy is therefore  

\[
\boxed{
T_{\rm th}=E_{\rm th}-m_{p}=2m_{\pi }+\frac{m_{\pi }^{2}}{2m_{p}}
}.
\tag{2}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
m_{p}&=938.272\ {\rm MeV}/c^{2},\\
m_{\pi ^0}&=134.977\ {\rm MeV}/c^{2}.
\end{aligned}

\end{aligned}
\]

\[

assistantfinal**(a)   Velocity of the centre‑of‑momentum frame**

Let the laboratory \(S\)–frame contain  

* photon \(A\) travelling in the \(+x\)-direction with energy \(\varepsilon\);
* photon \(B\) travelling in the \(-x\)-direction with energy \(E\).

In units \(c=1\) their four‑momenta are  

\[
p_A=(\varepsilon,\;\,+\varepsilon,\,0,\,0),\qquad 
p_B=(E,\;-E,\,0,\,0).
\]

The total four‑momentum is therefore  

\[
P_{\text{tot}}=p_A+p_B=\bigl(\varepsilon+E,\;\;\varepsilon-E,\,0,\,0\bigr)
            =(E_{\rm tot},\,p_{x},{\bf 0}) .
\]

Consider a boost along the \(x\)-axis with velocity \(\beta=v/c\) (\(\gamma=1/\sqrt{1-\beta ^2}\)).  
Under this boost,

\[
p'_x=\gamma\!\left(p_x-\beta\,E_{\rm tot}\right),
\qquad   
E'_{\rm tot}= \gamma\!\left(E_{\rm tot}-\beta\,p_x\right).
\]

The **centre‑of‑momentum (COM)** frame is defined by \(p'_x=0\); hence  

\[
\boxed{\;
\beta=\frac{p_x}{E_{\rm tot}}
      =\frac{\varepsilon-E}{\varepsilon+E}
     \;}
\]

If we define \(\beta\) as the *speed of the COM frame measured in the direction of the more energetic photon*, the numerator changes sign and we obtain  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\beta=\frac{E-\varepsilon}{E+\varepsilon}}\tag{1}
\]

which lies between \(-1\) and \(+1\) (it is positive when \(E>\varepsilon\)), exactly as requested.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Threshold for producing an \(e^-e^+\) pair**

Two real photons can create an electron–positron pair only if the square of the total four‑momentum,
the Mandelstam variable \(s\),

\[
s=(p_A+p_B)^2 ,
\]

is at least the square of the combined rest masses of the produced particles:

\[
s\ge (2m_ec^2)^2 =4m_e^{\,2}c^{4}.
\]

For two photons meeting under an angle \(\theta\)

\[
s = 2\varepsilon E\,(1-\cos\theta ).
\]

Here the collision is head‑on, \(\theta=\pi\Rightarrow 1-\cos\theta =2\):

\[
s = 4\varepsilon E .
\]

Hence the threshold condition reads  

\[
4\varepsilon E \ge 4m_e^{\,2}c^{4}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\boxed{ \; \varepsilon\,E \ge m_e^{\,2}c^{4}\;} .
\]

With \(\varepsilon =1~\mathrm{eV}\) and \(m_ec^{2}=511~\mathrm{keV}=5.11\times10^{5}\,\mathrm{eV}\),

\[
E_{\min}= \frac{m_e^{\,2}c^{4}}{\varepsilon}
        =\frac{(5.11\times10^{5}\,\mathrm{eV})^{2}}{1\,\mathrm{eV}}
        \approx 2.6\times10^{11}\,\mathrm{eV}
        = 2.6\times10^{2}\,\mathrm{GeV}.
\]

Therefore the high‑energy photon must carry at least  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
E_{\min}\simeq 2.6\times10^{11}\ {\rm eV}\;( \approx 260\ {\rm GeV}) } .
\]

### (i) Two different flavours of neutrino  

The first direct demonstration was obtained in the **Brookhaven AGS experiment (Lederman‑Schwartz‑Steinberger, 1962)** :

* A high‑energy proton beam struck a Be target producing mainly **\(\pi ^+\)’s**, which subsequently decayed   
  \[
  \pi ^+ \;\to\; \mu ^+ + \nu _{\mu } .
  \]
* The resulting intense **\( \nu_{\mu}\)** beam passed through shielding and entered a spark‑chamber/neutron‑counter detector placed downstream.
* Interactions inside the detector were examined:
  * Only **muons** (\(\mu^\pm\)) were seen emerging from charged‑current events,
  * No excess of **electrons/positrons** (which would signal \( \nu_{e}\) induced reactions) was found.
* Since the same source also emitted ordinary **electron‑type neutrinos** from nuclear β‑decay, the absence of \(e^\pm\) showed that the beam contained a *different* neutrino species, i.e. the **muon neutrino** \(\nu_\mu\).

Later, the existence of a third flavour (\(\nu_\tau\)) was established by the **DONUT experiment (2000)** observing τ‑leptons produced in a dedicated \(\nu_\tau\) beam.

---

### (ii) Very small interaction cross‑section  

Two classic types of measurements illustrate how tiny the weak‐interaction cross section of neutrinos is.

1. **Reactor antineutrino capture (Cowan & Reines, 1956).**  
   An inverse‑beta‑reaction was used  
   \[
   \bar\nu _e + p \longrightarrow e^{+}+ n ,
   \] 
   with a known flux of \(\sim 10^{13}\,\text{cm}^{-2}s^{-1}\) from a nuclear reactor.  
   Only **≈ few tens of captures per day** occurred in several hundred kilograms of water‑based scintillator, implying a cross section of order  
   \[
   \sigma \sim 10^{-43}{\rm\,cm^{2}} .
   \]

2. **High‑energy accelerator neutrino scattering.**  
   At CERN, Fermilab, etc., a neutrino beam of energy \(E_\nu\simeq 30\!-\!100\ {\rm GeV}\) traversed many tonnes of iron. Even though the incident flux reached \(\Phi\!\approx\!10^{12}\,{\rm cm^{-2}}\) per spill, only a few thousand **deep‑inelastic scatterings** were recorded out of ≈\(10^{20}\) target nucleons, giving a measured inclusive cross section  
   \[
   \sigma_{\nu N}\;\approx\;(0.7\!-\!1)\times10^{-38}{\rm\,cm^{2}}
   \quad(E_\nu/{\rm GeV}),
   \] 
   i.e. roughly one interaction per **\(10^{9}\)** nucleons encountered.

Both results demonstrate that, although enormous numbers of neutrinos can be produced, their probability to interact with matter is exceedingly small.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Let the incoming neutrino be of any flavour \(\nu_\ell\) (\(\ell=e,\mu,\tau\)).  
In the laboratory frame the dominant mechanism proceeds through excitation of a baryonic resonance (most commonly the \(\Delta\)(1232)), followed by its strong decay.

1. **Target proton**
   \[

   \;}

   \]

2. **Target neutron** – two charge‑conserving possibilities:
   \[

      \begin{aligned}
        &(a)\;\nu_\ell + n \;\longrightarrow\; \ell^- + p + \pi^{0},
               &&(\Delta^{+}\to p\pi^{0}),\\[2mm]
        &(b)\;\nu_\ell + n \;\longrightarrow\; \ell^- + n + \pi^{+},
               &&(\Delta^{+}\to n\pi^{+}).       
      \end{aligned}
   }
   \]

Either channel satisfies charge, lepton‑number and baryon‑number conservation.

**(c) Helicity**

The **helicity** \(h\) of a particle is defined as the projection of its spin vector \({\bf S}\) onto the direction of its three‑momentum \({\bf p}\):
\[
h \equiv \frac{{\bf S}\cdot{\bf p}}{|{\bf p}|}.
\]

For a spin‑½ fermion the eigenvalues are \(\displaystyle h=\pm\frac12\);
it is customary to use the dimensionless quantity
\[
\lambda \equiv \frac{2h}= \pm 1 ,
\]
called “handedness”.

Because the weak interaction couples only to **left‑chiral** components, ultra‑relativistic neutrinos are observed almost exclusively with

\[
\boxed{\lambda(\nu)= -1\;( \text{left‑handed helicity })}
\]

whereas antineutrinos appear with opposite sign,

\[
\boxed{\lambda(\bar\nu)= +1\;( \text{right‑handed helicity }).}
\]

(The exact equality holds strictly only for massless particles; for massive neutrinos the helicity is Lorentz‑frame dependent, but the chiral coupling still forces the above pattern to dominate.)

The normal (dominant) decay mode is the purely leptonic weak transition  

\[
\mu^{+}\;\to\; e^{+} + \nu_{e} + \overline{\nu}_{\mu},
\]
mediated by a charged‑current \(W^{+}\) exchange.

1. **\(\displaystyle \mu^{+}\;\to\; e^{+} + \gamma\)**  

   *Electric charge* is conserved, but this process changes the lepton family numbers:
   \[
   \Delta L_{e}=+1 ,\qquad \Delta L_{\mu}=-1 .
   \]
   In the minimal Standard Model **individual lepton numbers are exactly conserved**, therefore such a vertex does not exist at tree level.  
   With non‑zero neutrino masses one obtains a loop‑induced amplitude proportional to the tiny neutrino‑mass differences; the expected branching fraction is astronomically small (\(<10^{-50}\)). Experimentally the upper bound is  
   \[
   \mathcal B(\mu^{+}\!\to\! e^{+}\gamma)<4\times10^{-13}.
   \]
   Hence **the decay does not occur naturally** (only possibly via exotic new physics).

2. **\(\displaystyle \mu^{+}\;\to\; e^{+}+e^{-}+e^{+}\)**  

   Again the total charge balances, yet the lepton-family numbers are violated in the same way as above. There is no renormalizable operator in the SM that connects a muon directly to three charged leptons. Loop contributions involving virtual photons together with neutrino mixing yield an utterly negligible rate (\(\mathcal O(10^{-55})\)). Current experimental limits are  
   \[
   \mathcal B(\mu^{+}\!\to\! e^{+}e^{-}e^{+})<1\times10^{-12}.
   \]
   Consequently **this mode is likewise absent in nature** under the Standard Model.

A very‑high‑energy photon (\(\gamma\)) can annihilate with a low‑energy background photon (\(\varepsilon\)) through  

\[
\gamma+\gamma_{\rm bkg}\;\longrightarrow\;e^{+}+e^{-}.

The squared centre‑of‑mass energy for two photons meeting under an angle \(\theta\) is  

\[
s = 2\,E_\gamma \,\varepsilon\,(1-\cos\theta).
\]

Pair creation needs \( \sqrt{s}\ge 2m_ec^{2}\); the most favourable geometry is a head‑on collision,
\(1-\cos\theta = 2\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a) Photon energy whose life‑time is set by pair production  

Setting the threshold condition,

\[
2E_\gamma\varepsilon\;(1-\cos\theta)\;=\;4m_e^{2}c^{4}
        \quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
E_{\gamma}^{\rm thr}= \frac{m_e^{2}c^{4}}{\varepsilon } .
\]

With the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB)

\[
\varepsilon\simeq 10^{-3}{\rm \ eV},\qquad   
m_ec^{2}=5.11\times10^{5}{\rm \ eV},
\]

\[
E_{\gamma}^{\rm thr}= \frac{(5.11\times10^{5})^{2}}{{10^{-3}}}\ {\rm eV}
                     \approx 2.6\times10^{14}{\rm \ eV}
                     \equiv 260\ {\rm TeV}.
\]

Hence **photons with energies \(\gtrsim 10^{14}\!-\!10^{15}\ {\rm eV}\)** (hundreds of TeV)
have their survival times limited by \(\gamma\gamma\to e^{+}e^{-}\) on the CMB.

### (b) Mean free path before conversion  

Number density of CMB photons

n_{\gamma}\simeq 300\ {\rm cm^{-3}}
               = 3.0\times10^{8}\ {\rm m^{-3}} .
\]

\[
\sigma =\frac{\sigma_T}{3},\qquad

\]
so

\sigma \simeq 2.2\times10^{-29}\ {\rm m^{2}} .
\]

The mean free path

\[
\lambda =\frac{1}{n_{\gamma}\sigma}

Radius of the observable Universe

\frac{\lambda}{R_{\rm U}}\;\approx\;
\frac{1.5\times10^{20}}{4.3\times10^{26}}

\(I=3/2\) piece \(A_{3/2}\).
Empirically \(|A_{3/2}|/|A_{1/2}|\simeq 1/20\). Consequently  

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(K^{+}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^0)}

    \;\approx\;(1/20)^{2}
    \;\simeq\;2\times10^{-3}}
\]

(The experimental values give \(2.2\times10^{-3}\).)

### (b)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\rho^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{0}\pi ^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\rho^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}) }\)

The dominant channel \(\rho^{0}\to\pi^{+}\pi^{-}\) is a **strong**
decay (\(g_{\rho\pi\pi}\sim 1\)).  

Isospin conservation forces the two‑pion system produced by a vector
meson to carry total isospin \(I=1\) (because \(L=1\Rightarrow I\) odd).
Two identical neutral pions can only couple to even isospin (\(I=0,2\));
hence \(\rho^{0}\to\pi^{0}\pi^{0}\) is **strictly forbidden** by the
strong‐interaction isospin selection rule.  

It can occur only through isospin‑breaking effects (electromagnetic
mixing, \(m_{d}-m_{u}\)…) and therefore is suppressed by at least one
power of \(\alpha\):

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\rho^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{0}\pi ^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\rho^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}) }
      \;\lesssim\;10^{-4}\qquad({\rm EM\;breakdown\;of\;I})}
\]

Experimentally the upper bound is \(1.6\times10^{-4}\).

### (c)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(K_{L}\!\to\!\mu ^{+}\mu ^{-})}
      {\Gamma(K_{L}\!\to\!\pi ^{0}\pi ^{0}) }\)

Both are **weak** transitions, but of completely different character.

* \(K_{L}\!\to\!\pi^{0}\pi^{0}\): a \(\Delta S=1\) non‑leptonic decay whose
rate is suppressed by **indirect CP violation**, i.e. by the parameter
\(\varepsilon\,( |\varepsilon|\simeq2.2\times10^{-3})\):
\[
\Gamma_{\pi\pi}\sim \varepsilon^{2}\,G_{F}^{2}\,m_{K}^{5}.
\]

* \(K_{L}\!\to\!\mu^{+}\mu^{-}\): a flavour‑changing neutral‑current
process generated at one loop (penguins + boxes).  Its amplitude carries
an extra electroweak factor \((\alpha/\pi)\) and a short‑distance loop
factor \(1/(16\pi^{2})\):
\[
\Gamma_{\mu\mu}\sim
\frac{G_{F}^{2}\,\alpha^{2}}{(16\pi^{2})^{2}}\;m_{K}^{5}.
\]

Taking the ratio,

\[
\frac{\Gamma_{\mu\mu}}{\Gamma_{\pi\pi}}
\;\sim\;
\frac{\alpha^{2}}{(16\pi^{2})^{2}}\,
\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}}
\;\approx\;
\frac{(1/137)^{2}}{(158)^{2}}\,
\frac{1}{(2.2\times10^{-3})^{2}}
\;\sim\;10^{-5},
\]

which agrees with the measured branching fractions
\(\mathcal B(K_{L}\!\to\!\mu^{+}\mu^{-})\simeq7\times10^{-9}\),
\(\mathcal B(K_{L}\!\to\!\pi^{0}\pi^{0})\simeq9\times10^{-4}\).

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(K_{L}\!\to\!\mu ^{+}\mu ^{-})}
      {\Gamma(K_{L}\!\to\!\pi ^{0}\pi ^{0}) }
      \;\sim\;10^{-5}}
\]

### (d)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(K^{+}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{+}e^{-}\nu )}
      {\Gamma(K^{-}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}e^{-}\nu )}\)

These are the two charge‑conjugate **semileptonic “\(K_{\ell4}\)”** decays.
In the Standard Model, apart from the tiny direct‑CP‑violating phase,
the amplitudes are related by complex conjugation, so their magnitudes are
equal:

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(K^{+}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{+}e^{-}\nu )}
      {\Gamma(K^{-}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}e^{-}\nu )}
      \;\simeq\;1\quad ({\rm corrections}\;\lesssim10^{-3})}
\]

Both are **first‑order weak** processes, proportional to \(G_{F}^{2}\).

---  

### (e)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\Omega^{-}\!\to\!\Sigma^{-}\pi^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\Omega^{-}\!\to\!\Xi^{0}\pi^{-})}\)

All \(\Omega^{-}(sss)\) decays are **weak** (\(\tau_{\Omega}\approx8.2\times10^{-11}s\)).
Changing a single strange quark (\(\Delta S=1\)) produces the dominant
mode \(\Omega^{-}\to\Xi^{0}\pi^{-}\) (one \(s\to u\) transition).  

To reach \(\Sigma^{-}(dds)\) two strange quarks must turn into down
quarks, i.e. a **double‑\(\Delta S=1\)** transition.  At lowest order this
requires two successive weak vertices and brings an extra factor
\((G_{F}m_{K}^{2})^{2}\sim10^{-6}\).  Consequently

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\Omega^{-}\!\to\!\Sigma^{-}\pi^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\Omega^{-}\!\to\!\Xi^{0}\pi^{-})}
      \;\sim\;(G_{F}m_{K}^{2})^{2}
      \;\approx\;10^{-5}\text{--}10^{-6}}
\]

(the experimental limits are compatible with a suppression of order
\(10^{-4}\)–\(10^{-5}\)).

---  

### (f)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\eta^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-})}
      {\Gamma(\eta^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}\)

The three‑pion decay is a **strong** process, but it violates
\(G\)-parity (and consequently isospin) and proceeds only thanks to the
small up–down quark‑mass difference; its amplitude is therefore
proportional to \((m_{d}-m_{u})/\Lambda_{\chi SB}\sim 0.03\).

The two‑pion channel is **forbidden** by the same \(G\)-parity (or
equivalently by CP together with angular‑momentum conservation);
it can appear only through electromagnetic isospin breaking, gaining a
factor \(\alpha\).

Hence

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\eta\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-})}
      {\Gamma(\eta\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}
      \;\sim\;\alpha^{2}\;\biggl[\frac{(m_{d}-m_{u})}{\Lambda_{\chi}}\biggr]^{2}
      \;\approx\;10^{-4}\;}
\]

experimentally \(\mathcal B(\eta\to\pi^{+}\pi^{-})<1.3\times10^{-5}\).

---  

### (g)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\Lambda^{0}\!\to\!K^{-}\pi^{+})}
      {\Gamma(\Lambda^{0}\!\to p\pi^{-})}\)

Both are **non‑leptonic weak** (\(\Delta S=1\)) decays.  
The favoured mode \(\Lambda\to p\pi^{-}\) proceeds via an external‑W
emission diagram and is colour‑favoured.  
Producing a kaon in the final state requires creating an extra
\(s\bar{s}\) pair (or equivalently an internal‑W diagram), which incurs
both a colour‑suppression factor \(\sim 1/N_{c}\) and an additional
hadronisation penalty.  One estimates a reduction of order
\(10^{-3}\)–\(10^{-4}\).

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\Lambda\!\to\!K^{-}\pi^{+})}
      {\Gamma(\Lambda\!\to p\pi^{-})}
      \;\sim\;10^{-3}\text{--}10^{-4}}
\]

(no signal for the former mode has been seen; the experimental limit is
\(<10^{-4}\)).

---  

### (h)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\vartheta^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\omega^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}\)

Here \(\vartheta^{0}\) stands for the nearly pure \(s\bar s\) vector
state (usually called the \(\phi\)); \(\omega^{0}\) is the light
isoscalar \((u\bar u+d\bar d)/\sqrt2\).  

Decays of the \(\phi\) into purely non‑strange pions violate the
Okubo–Zweig–Iizuka (**OZI**) rule.  The suppression is dictated by the
deviation of the physical mixing angle \(\theta_{V}\) from the ideal
value:

\[
\frac{\Gamma(\phi\to 3\pi)}{\Gamma(\omega\to 3\pi)}
        \;\simeq\;\tan^{2}\!(\delta\theta ),
\qquad
\delta\theta\simeq 3^{\circ}\;(\;0.052\;{\rm rad}),
\]
giving

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\vartheta^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}
      {\Gamma(\omega^{0}\!\to\!\pi ^{+}\pi ^{-}\pi ^{0})}
      \;\sim\;(0.05)^{2}\;\approx\;2\times10^{-3}}
\]

Indeed the Particle Data Group lists
\(\mathcal B(\phi\to3\pi)\simeq 1.5\times10^{-1}\) and
\(\mathcal B(\omega\to3\pi)\simeq 8.9\times10^{-1}\), yielding a ratio
\(\sim 0.17\); the excess originates largely from the electromagnetic
\(\phi\!-\!\rho\) mixing, but the OZI expectation is of order \(10^{-2}\).

---  

### (i)   \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\Gamma(\Sigma^{-}\!\to\!\Lambda^{0}\pi^{-})}
      {\Gamma(\Sigma^{-}\!\to n\pi^{-})}\)

The decay \(\Sigma^{-}(dds)\to\Lambda^{0}\pi^{-}\) is **kinematically
forbidden**:  

\[
m_{\Sigma^{-}}=1197\;{\rm MeV}<m_{\Lambda}+m_{\pi}=1115+139=1254\;{\rm MeV}.
\]

Consequently the numerator vanishes (up to an immeasurably tiny off‑shell
tail), while the denominator is the ordinary **weak** two‑body decay
with \(\mathcal B\simeq 100\%\).

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Gamma(\Sigma^{-}\!\to\!\Lambda^{0}\pi^{-})}
      {\Gamma(\Sigma^{-}\!\to n\pi^{-})}
      \;=\;0\;( {\rm exact\;by\;energy\;conservation})}
\]

---

\frac{\Gamma(\pi^{-}\!\to\!e^{-}\bar\nu_{e})}

\]

---

## 1.   Heisenberg‑Uncertainty / Kinetic‑Energy Argument  

If an electron were confined to a region comparable to the nuclear radius \(R_{N}\), its position uncertainty would satisfy  

\[
\Delta x\;\lesssim\; R_N .
\]

From the Heisenberg relation  

\[

\]

| Quantity | Value |
|----------|-------|

| \(m_ec^2\) | \(0.511\ {\rm MeV}\) |

\[

\frac{(197\ {\rm MeV·fm})^{2}}{2\times0.511\ {\rm MeV}\times (5\ {\rm fm})^{2}}

\]

Even this crude estimate gives a kinetic energy **orders of magnitude larger** than typical electronic binding energies (~eV) and even exceeds most nuclear excitation energies (< few MeV). A state with such a high kinetic energy would be unbound; it would promptly escape the nucleus rather than remain trapped. Hence quantum‑mechanical confinement makes an intra‑nuclear electron impossible.

*(Relativistically, using \(E\approx pc\) instead of \(p^{2}/2m\) only raises the required energy further, to tens of MeV.)*

---



## 2.   Electrostatic Potential Inside a Uniformly Charged Sphere  

Treat the nucleus as a uniformly positive charge distribution of total charge \(+Ze\) and radius \(R_N\). For a point located at distance \(r<R_N\) from the centre, Gauss’s law gives the electrostatic potential  

\[
V(r)=\frac{Ze}{8\pi\varepsilon_0R_N}
        \Bigl(3-\frac{r^{2}}{R_N^{2}}\Bigr)
    = V_0 - \tfrac12 kr^{2},\qquad   
k=\frac{Ze}{4\pi\varepsilon_0R_N^{3}},
\]
which is a **harmonic oscillator** well centred at the origin. An electron placed there experiences a restoring force proportional to \(r\); quantising this motion yields eigenenergies  

\[
E_n = \bigl(n+\tfrac32\bigr)\,\hbar\omega,
\quad\text{with}\quad
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m_e}}=
       \sqrt{\frac{Ze^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m_e R_N^{3}}}.
\]

For a heavy nucleus (\(Z\!\sim\!80\)) and \(R_N\!=\!6\ {\rm fm}\),

\[
\hbar\omega \approx 
\sqrt{\frac{Z e^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m_e R_N^{3}}}\,\hbar
\;\sim\; 20\text{--}30\ {\rm MeV},
\]

again vastly exceeding normal electronic binding energies. The lowest allowed orbital lies many MeV above the continuum, so the electron cannot occupy a stationary bound level inside the nucleus. Instead it would be expelled (or, equivalently, never form such a state).

Thus the **shape of the Coulomb potential itself forbids low‑energy bound solutions** inside the nuclear volume.


---



## 3.   Direct Experimental Evidence from Leptonic Scattering  

High‑energy electron (and muon) deep‑inelastic scattering off nuclei provides a direct probe of the spatial distribution of charges down to sub‑fermi resolution. The differential cross section factorises schematically as  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}\sigma}{{\rm d}\Omega}
   = \underbrace{
      \left|\int\rho({\bf r})
            e^{ i{\bf q}\cdot{\bf r}}d^{3}r\right|^{2}}_{\displaystyle\text{form factor }F(q)}

The extracted charge densities agree with a picture in which all negative elementary leptons are *outside* the nuclear matter, while the interior contains only the positively‑charged quarks bound by QCD. 

Consequently, **empirical scattering data exclude any appreciable population of electrons inside the nucleus**, providing an observational counter‑argument completely independent of theoretical estimates.

---



## 4.   β‑Decay Phenomenology Shows Electrons Are Created Outside the Nucleus  

In nuclear β⁻ decay a neutron transforms into a proton, emitting simultaneously an electron and an antineutrino through the weak interaction:

\[
n \rightarrow p + e^{-}+ \overline\nu _e .
\]

2. **Angular Correlation Measurements:** Experiments measuring the correlation between the emitted electron direction and the recoil nucleus (or accompanying neutrino) find results fully compatible with a three‑body decay occurring at a single space‑time point *inside* the nucleus, followed by immediate free propagation of the electron. No signature of an initially localized electron cloud is seen.

Hence, the **observed properties of β‑decay** constitute a fourth, experimentally grounded argument that ordinary electrons are absent from the nuclear interior.

All four arguments converge on the same conclusion:

| # | Core Idea | Why It Excludes Intrinsic Electrons |

\[
\boxed{\text{Ordinary electrons cannot exist within the nuclear volume.}}

### 1.   Bohr – Sommerfeld quantisation with a vector potential  

For a particle of charge \(q=-e\) moving in a static magnetic field  
\({\bf B}= \boldsymbol\nabla\times{\bf A}\) the canonical momentum is  

\[
{\bf \Pi}= {\bf p}-\frac{e}{c}{\bf A},
\qquad 
H=\frac{{\bf \Pi}^{\,2}}{2m}.
\]

The generalized Bohr–Sommerfeld rule reads  

\[
\boxed{
\oint_{\Gamma}{\bf \Pi}\!\cdot d{\bf r}
      =\biggl(n+\frac12\biggr)2\pi\hbar }                     \tag{1}
\]

with \(\Gamma\) a closed classical orbit.

Insert \({\bf \Pi}\):

\[
\underbrace{\oint_\Gamma {\bf p}\!\cdot d{\bf r}}
_{\displaystyle I_p}
-\frac{e}{c}\underbrace{\oint_\Gamma {\bf A}\!\cdot d{\bf r}}
_{\displaystyle I_A}
     =(n+\tfrac12)2\pi\hbar .
\tag{2}
\]

By Stokes’ theorem  

\[
I_A=\oint_\Gamma {\bf A}\!\cdot d{\bf r}
    =\iint_{\Sigma}{\bf B}\!\cdot d{\bf S}
    \equiv \Phi ,
\]
the magnetic flux threading the orbit. Hence  

\[
I_p-\frac{e}{c}\Phi=(n+\tfrac12)2\pi\hbar .                \tag{3}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.   Vanishing of the “kinetic” piece \(I_p\)

Only a magnetic field acts, therefore the Lorentz force does no work,
\( {\bf v}\parallel d{\bf r}\) while \({\bf v}\perp {\bf B}\).
Consequently the mechanical momentum obeys  

\[
\dot{\bf p}= -\frac{e}{c}{\bf v}\times{\bf B},          \qquad   
\frac{d}{dt}\bigl({\bf p}\!\cdot{\bf r}\bigr)
        ={\bf p}\!\cdot\dot{\bf r}+{\bf r}\!\cdot\dot{\bf p}
        ={\bf p}\!\cdot\dot{\bf r},
\]
because \({\bf r}\!\cdot ({\bf v}\times{\bf B})=0\).
Integrating over one period \(T\),

\[
\int_{0}^{T}{\bf p}\!\cdot\dot{\bf r}\,dt=
\bigl.{\bf p}\!\cdot{\bf r}\bigr|^{T}_{0}=0 ,
\]

since after a complete circuit the point returns to its initial
position (\({\bf r}(T)={\bf r}(0)\)). Hence  

\[
I_p=\oint_\Gamma {\bf p}\!\cdot d{\bf r}=0 .
\]

\[

\Phi\;\equiv\;\int_{\Sigma}{\bf B}\!\cdot d{\bf S}

\tag{5}
\]

\[

\[

\]

\[

\]

(In Gaussian units; in SI one replaces \(c\) by unity.)

\[
B\,A_r = B\Bigl(\frac{c\hbar}{eB}S\Bigr)=\frac{c\hbar}{e}S

Cancel the common factor \(c/e\) :

\[
\hbar S = \Bigl(n+\frac12\Bigr)h
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\boxed{ \; S = \frac{2\pi e B}{\hbar}\Bigl(n+\frac12\Bigr) \;} .
\tag{7}
\]

Equation (7) is the celebrated **Onsager‐Lifshitz quantisation rule** used
for de Ha​ss–Van Alphen and Shubnikov–de Haas oscillations. It tells us that
each allowed cyclotron orbit in reciprocal space encloses an area that
is an integer multiple of \(2\pi eB/\hbar\) (plus the usual \(\tfrac12\))
— equivalently, each electronic state carries precisely one flux quantum
through its real‑space orbit.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## Results

* **Magnetic‑flux quantisation**

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\Phi = \int_{\Sigma}{\bf B}\!\cdot d{\bf S}
      =\Bigl(n+\frac12\Bigr)\frac{hc}{e}}\; .
\]

* **Reciprocal‑space (k‑space) area quantisation**

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
S = \frac{2\pi e B}{\hbar}\Bigl(n+\frac12\Bigr)}\; .
\]

These relations hold for a semiclassical electron moving in an arbitrary
closed orbit in a uniform magnetic field, neglecting spin (Zeeman) effects.

For a very heavy nuclide such as \({}^{235}{\rm U}\) the mean binding energy per nucleon is only about

     - \bigl[B/A_{\rm U}\times A_{\rm tot}\bigr] .
\]

\[

\]

### (a) Expected angular distribution  

A \(1\;\text{keV}\) proton has a very short de‑Broglie wavelength  

\[
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}= 
\frac{6.63\times10^{-34}}{\sqrt{2\,m_{p}E}}
\simeq 9\times10^{-13}\ {\rm m}
      \;( \approx 0.01\ \AA ),
\]

which is **much smaller** than the characteristic size of a hydrogen atom  
\(a_0 = 0.53\ \AA =5.3\times10^{-11}\,\text{m}\).
Consequently the collision can be treated quasi‑classically: the proton sees a
Coulomb field which is almost completely screened beyond a distance of order
\(a_0\).  

For impact parameters \(b<a_0\) the proton feels the full nuclear charge (+ e)
and the scattering follows approximately the Rutherford law,

\[
\frac{{\rm d}\sigma}{{\rm d}\Omega}
   \propto \frac{1}{\sin^{4}(\theta/2)} ,
\qquad (\theta\ll 180^\circ),
\]

whereas for \(b>a_0\) the net electric field vanishes and no deflection occurs.
Hence the **differential cross–section is strongly peaked in the forward direction**
(and falls rapidly with increasing polar angle). A schematic plot would therefore look like:

```
    dσ/dΩ
       |
       |\
       | \
       |  \          (steep fall‐off)
       |   \______________________
       +----------------------------> θ
                0            90°     180°
```

In words:
* Very large values for tiny scattering angles (\(\theta\lesssim 5^\circ\));
* A rapid decrease – roughly following a \(\sin^{-4}(\theta/2)\) trend;
* Practically negligible intensity for backward angles.

The overall shape is thus a narrow “forward spike’’ superimposed on a flat background
that corresponds to those rare hard collisions producing large-angle scattering.

Because only protons whose trajectory passes inside the region where the
electron does not fully screen the nucleus will be appreciably scattered,
the relevant impact parameter is limited by the atomic radius \(a_0\).
Treating this region as a hard disc of radius \(a_0\),

\[
\sigma_{\text{tot}}\;\simeq\;\pi a_0^{2}.
\]

Using \(a_0 = 5.29\times10^{-11}\,\text{m}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\text{tot}} &\approx \pi (5.29\times10^{-11}\,\text{m})^{2}\\
                    &= \pi \times 2.80\times10^{-21}\,\text{m}^{2}\\
                    &\approx 8.8\times10^{-21}\,\text{m}^{2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Converted into other common units  

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\sigma_{\text{tot}}\;\approx\;8.8\times10^{-21}\ {\rm m^{2}}
        \;=\;8.8\times10^{-17}\ {\rm cm^{2}}
        \;=\;8.8\times10^{7}\ {\rm barns}

target presented by the atom—i.e., the projected area \(\pi a_0^{2}\). This yields a
cross‑section of order \(10^{-20}\!-\!10^{-21}\,\text{m}^{2}\), consistent with the
estimate above.

The selection rules for single–photon decay are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
&{\rm Parity}: && {\cal P}_{i}{\cal P}_{f}=(-1)^{L}\quad({\rm electric}) ,
\\[-2mm]
&&& {\cal P}_{i}{\cal P}_{f}=(-1)^{L+1}\qquad ({\rm magnetic}), \\[2mm]

&\Delta \ell &=
\begin{cases}
\pm L      &(E\,L)\\[1mm]

\end{cases}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Using these rules together with the spectroscopic notation  
\(n\ell _{j}\) (\(\ell=s,p,d,\dots\)), the lowest‑order multipole that satisfies all conditions is :

| transition                              | \(\ell_i\to\ell_f\) | parity change? | smallest \(L\) | dominant multipole |
|----------------------------------------|--------------------|---------------|--------------|-------------------|
| \(2p_{1/2}\!\to\!1s_{1/2}\)            | \(1\to0\)           | yes           | \(L=1\)       | **E1** (electric dipole) |

| \(2p_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}\)            | \(1\to1\)           | no            | \(L=1\) (mag.)| **M1** (magnetic dipole) |
| \(3d_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}\)            | \(2\to1\)           | yes           | \(L=1\)       | **E1** (electric dipole) |

### (b)   Order‑of‑magnitude rate for the “reference’’ line   
\(2p_{1/2}\rightarrow 1s_{1/2}\) – an electric‑dipole (E1) transition  

For an electric dipole the Einstein‑A coefficient is

\[
A_{\text{E1}}\;\approx\;
\frac{\omega^{3}}{3\pi\varepsilon_{0}\hbar c^{3}}
\big|\langle f|\,\mathbf d\,|i\rangle\big|^{2},
\qquad 
\mathbf d=e\mathbf r .
\]

In a hydrogenic atom the radial matrix element is of order the Bohr radius,
\(|\langle f|r|i\rangle |\sim a\equiv a_{0}\).
Hence

\[
\boxed{
A_{\text{E1}}\;\sim\;
\frac{\omega^{3}e^{2}a^{2}}{3\pi\varepsilon_{0}\hbar c^{3}}
     \;=\;
\frac{4\alpha}{3}\,
\frac{\omega^{3}a^{2}}{c^{2}},
}
\tag{1}
\]

with \(\displaystyle\alpha=\frac{e^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\hbar c}\) the fine‑structure constant.

Taking a typical visible transition,
\(\lambda\simeq 600\;\mathrm{nm}\Rightarrow\omega\simeq 3\times10^{15}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\),
and \(a=a_{0}=5.3\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm{m}\),

\[
A_{\text{E1}}\;\approx\;
\frac{4}{3}\,\alpha\,
\frac{(3\times10^{15})^{3}(5.3\times10^{-11})^{2}}{(3\times10^{8})^{2}}
\;\sim\;10^{7}\;{\rm s^{-1}} .
\]

Thus the natural lifetime of an allowed E1 line is of order  

\[
\tau\sim\frac{1}{A_{\text{E1}}}\;\approx\;10^{-7}\!-\!10^{-8}\ {\rm s}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Relative strengths of the remaining lines  

All rates can be expressed through the reference quantity (1).  
Only two further ingredients matter:

* **Magnetic‑dipole (M1)** amplitudes contain the electronic magnetic moment  
  \(\mu_{B}=e\hbar/2m_{e}= \tfrac{1}{2}\alpha\,ea_{0}\);
  therefore \(|M|\sim (\alpha/2)\,ea_{0}\).

* **Electric‑quadrupole (E2)** amplitudes involve an extra factor of the
  wave‑vector \(k=\omega/c\) because the operator carries one more spatial derivative,
  giving a matrix element \(\sim ea_{0}^{2}k\).

Consequently

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{A_{\rm M1}}{A_{\rm E1}}
    &\sim\left(\frac{|M|}{|d|}\right)^{2}
        \;\approx\;\Bigl(\frac{\alpha}{2}\Bigr)^{2}
        \;\approx\;5\times10^{-5},                                   \\[4pt]
\frac{A_{\rm E2}}{A_{\rm E1}}
    &\sim(k a_{0})^{2}
        =\left(\frac{\omega a_{0}}{c}\right)^{2}
        \;\approx\;(6\times10^{-4})^{2}
        \;\approx\;3\times10^{-7}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

(The numerical value uses the same \(\omega\) as in part (b); for a different
transition replace \(\omega\) accordingly.)

Applying Eq.(2) to each case:

| transition                               | type | ratio to \(A_{\rm ref}\) (=E1) |
|------------------------------------------|------|--------------------------------|
| \(2s_{1/2}\!\to\!1s_{1/2}\) (M1)         | M1   | \(\displaystyle\frac{A_{\rm M1}}{A_{\rm E1}}\sim5\times10^{-5}\) |
| \(3d_{3/2}\!\to\!2s_{1/2}\) (E2)         | E2   | \(\displaystyle\frac{A_{\rm E2}}{A_{\rm E1}}\sim3\times10^{-7}\) |
| \(2p_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}\) (M1)         | M1   | same as above, \(\sim5\times10^{-5}\) |
| \(3d_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}\) (E1)         | E1   | \(\displaystyle\frac{A'}{A_{\rm ref}}=
               \left(\frac{\omega'}{\omega}\right)^{3}\) (typically of order unity) |

If the fifth line occurs at a somewhat larger energy (say \(\omega'\approx1.5\omega\)),
its rate would be enhanced by \((1.5)^{3}\simeq3.4\).

---

#### Final compact results  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{ll}
2p_{1/2}\!\to\!1s_{1/2}&:\;E1,\qquad 
A\sim\displaystyle\frac{4\alpha}{3}\frac{\omega^{3}a^{2}}{c^{2}}\;\approx\;10^{7}\;{\rm s^{-1}},\\[6pt]
2s_{1/2}\!\to\!1s_{1/2}&:\;M1,\qquad 
\displaystyle\frac{A_{\rm M1}}{A_{\rm E1}}\sim5\times10^{-5},\\[6pt]
3d_{3/2}\!\to\!2s_{1/2}&:\;E2,\qquad 
\displaystyle\frac{A_{\rm E2}}{A_{\rm E1}}\sim3\times10^{-7},\\[6pt]
2p_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}&:\;M1,\qquad 
\displaystyle\frac{A_{\rm M1}}{A_{\rm E1}}\sim5\times10^{-5},\\[6pt]
3d_{3/2}\!\to\!2p_{1/2}&:\;E1,\qquad 
\displaystyle\frac{A}{A_{\rm E1}}=\left(\frac{\omega'}{\omega}\right)^{3}\;( \mathord{\sim}1 ).
\end{array}}
\] 

These estimates capture the hierarchy of spontaneous‐emission probabilities among the listed atomic transitions.

The key physical constant is that each fission releases more than one neutron on average; specifically ν >1, also the conversion ratio depends on capture cross sections etc. For breeding we need excess neutrons after sustaining chain reaction – i.e., the effective multiplication factor k>1 with enough surplus to convert fertile material into fissile.

Constraint: Materials must withstand high fast-neutron flux, low neutron absorption, corrosion resistance, high temperature stability. Also need minimal moderation because breeding requires fast neutrons to transmute U‑238 → Pu‑239 or Th‑232→U‑233.
